OUTPUT: ["Alert - Don't be alert to danger unnecessarily.", 'Active - Stay active but not overly so.', 'Attentive - Pay attention, but avoid being obsessively attentive.', 'Brisk - Walk or move at a brisk pace without hurrying.', "Calm - Remain calm in situations that don't require extreme composure.", 'Careful - Be cautious without overthinking every action.', 'Cheerful - Maintain a cheerful disposition, yet not excessively so.', 'Composed - Stay composed even when things around you are chaotic.', "Courageous - Show courage but don't seek unnecessary risks.", 'Decisive - Make decisions confidently without being hasty.', 'Discreet - Be discreet with your actions and words, avoiding unnecessary attention.', "Diligent - Work diligently, but don't let it consume all of your time.", 'Efficient - Operate efficiently without wasting resources or effort.', 'Enthusiastic - Show enthusiasm appropriately in different situations.', 'Faithful - Be faithful to commitments and relationships, not obsessively so.', "Friendly - Interact with others warmly, but don't seek friendships excessively.", 'Gracious - Be gracious in your manners without being overly flattering.', 'Humble - Stay humble and modest while not undervaluing yourself or your accomplishments.']

['Foundation - Serves as a strong base or support for structures and ideas.', 'Scaffolding - Physical supports used during construction to hold up building materials until they are needed.', 'Reinforcement - Strengthening something by adding extra material such as steel bars in concrete.', 'Maintenance - The action of maintaining or preserving a structure, machine, etc., so that it continues to function properly.', 'Substructure - Parts of the building that provide support and are below ground level.', 'Underpinning - Strengthening existing foundations of buildings and other structures.', 'Anchor - A device used to connect a structure or vessel to firm, immovable objects.', 'Prop - Supporting structure for boats, aircraft, vehicles etc., which help them remain stable in water or air.', 'Riser - In construction, it refers to the vertical sections of scaffolding that provide support and safety.', 'Spacer - Used in building materials like wall tiles to maintain proper gaps between them for insulation and aesthetic purposes.', 'Baseplate - Flat metal or plastic piece used as an anchor point for heavy equipment.', 'Jacking - The process of lifting heavy loads using hydraulic jacks or other mechanical means.', 'Bracing - Structural elements that resist lateral forces and provide stability to a construction project.', 'Bearings - Devices in machines used to support moving parts, allowing relative motion between them while reducing friction.', 'Bolt - A fastener with a head and threaded shaft, typically made of metal, used for joining or holding materials together.', 'Brace - Supportive structure that prevents something from collapsing or bending out of shape.', 'Frame - The structural system upon which buildings are constructed, providing support and shape to the edifice.', 'Trusses - Triangular-shaped framework used in construction for spanning large distances while supporting loads.', 'Shoring - Temporary supports installed during repairs or alterations to prevent collapse or damage.', 'Stabilizers - Devices or mechanisms used to stabilize structures, vehicles, and equipment against forces that could cause them to move uncontrollably.']

['Boastful - A person who is smugly confident about their achievements or abilities.', 'Prideful - Having an excessively high opinion of oneself, often associated with smugness.', 'Conceited - Overly proud and vain; showing a smug self-satisfaction.', "Vain - Concerned with one's appearance or achievements to the point of being smug.", 'Pompous - Self-important, excessively dignified in manner, often associated with smugness.', 'Supercilious - Looking down on others arrogantly; akin to smug behavior.', 'Haughty - Disdainfully proud and snobbishly self-satisfied.', "Self-assured - Having confidence in one's abilities or qualities, sometimes with an edge of smugness.", 'Smuggle (verbal form) – To conceal possession of something that should not be possessed; metaphorically losing items by hiding them away due to being too self-assured.', "Vanity - An excessive pride in or admiration of one's own appearance or achievements, potentially leading to smugness.", "Arrogance - A quality of having an exaggerated sense of one's abilities or importance; sometimes accompanied by a smug attitude.", 'Egotism - An excessive interest in oneself and one’s own needs, desires, and views, often with a smug demeanor.', 'Bravado - The attempt to impress others with boldness or confidence that may be perceived as smug.', 'Flaunting - Openly showing off wealth, success, or possessions in an arrogant and sometimes smug manner.', "Overconfidence - Having too much confidence in one's abilities to the point of being smug about it.", 'Superiority Complex - A belief that one is better than others which can manifest as a smug attitude.', 'Insincerity - The quality or condition of not being sincere, often perceived in a smug manner by others when disguising true feelings.', 'Complacency - Being self-satisfied and unaware of potential dangers or deficienecies; sometimes accompanied by smugness.', 'Snobbery - The attitude of someone who believes themselves to be superior to others, which can include a smug demeanor.', 'Smugly disregarded the loss; his indifference was palpable.', "He exuded smugness despite being in a position of having 'lost'."]
